title: Research Introduction: AI vs. Non-AI Careers
text: The rise of artificial intelligence (AI) is transforming job markets globally. While AI-related jobs are in high demand, concerns about job displacement in traditional sectors (e.g., mechanical engineering, retail, farming) continue to grow. This research aims to analyze the impact of AI on job security, salary trends, and employment growth in AI-driven vs. non-AI industries.

title: Research Introduction: AI vs. Non-AI Careers
text: The rise of artificial intelligence (AI) is transforming job markets globally. While AI-related jobs are in high demand, concerns about job displacement in traditional sectors (e.g., mechanical engineering, retail, farming) continue to grow. This research aims to analyze the impact of AI on job security, salary trends, and employment growth in AI-driven vs. non-AI industries.

title: Research Introduction: AI vs. Non-AI Careers
text:
Literature Review
Existing research highlights the growing divide between AI-driven careers and traditional industries.

Smith and Zhao ((2023)) analyzed AI-driven job displacement and found that 30% of entry-level jobs in finance and marketing could be automated by 2026.

Johnson and Patel ((2024)) reported that data scientists earn 40% more than traditional engineers, leading to a wage polarization effect.

title: Research Introduction: AI vs. Non-AI Careers
text:
Analysis Plan
This research will use regression analysis to compare job security, salary trends, and employment growth in AI-driven vs. non-AI industries. The analysis will be based on data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics and LinkedIn.

title: Research Introduction: AI vs. Non-AI Careers

# Import iris from sklearn

from sklearn import datasets
import numpy as np

# Load the iris dataset
iris = datasets.load_iris()
iris_data = iris.data
iris_target = iris.target


# create dataframe
import pandas as pd
iris_df = pd.DataFrame(data=iris_data, columns=iris.feature_names)
